modules.description: This module provides direct control over terminal display and cursor movement, including clearing the screen or lines, moving the cursor in specific directions, and switching to an alternate screen buffer. It operates on basic integer and unit types to manipulate terminal state through low-level commands. Concrete use cases include building text-based user interfaces, implementing custom progress displays, or managing terminal output in interactive applications.

This module enables non-blocking UTF-8 input reading from standard input, returning either a string, end-of-input, or malformed data. It provides setup and shutdown functions to configure stdin for asynchronous reading using Unix terminal IO settings. Useful for interactive command-line applications needing immediate input response without blocking execution.

This module provides operations for generating ANSI escape sequences to control terminal behavior, including text styling (bold, colors), cursor positioning, screen manipulation (e.g., alternate screen switching), and terminal feature toggling (e.g., mouse support). It works directly with terminal display state and cursor coordinates to enable dynamic text rendering and interactive command-line interfaces. Specific use cases include building terminal emulators, text-based user interfaces, and applications requiring precise screen updates or enhanced terminal interactivity.

Represents terminal color profiles and provides functions to load the default profile, derive a profile from environment variables, and apply the profile to convert raw color values into terminal-compatible colors. Works with `Tty.Color.t` values, transforming them based on the loaded profile. Useful for ensuring consistent color output across different terminal environments by adapting color representations dynamically.

This module defines a type for terminal colors, supporting RGB, ANSI, and 256-color mode representations. It provides functions to construct and inspect color values, as well as convert them into escape sequences for foreground or background display. Use cases include styling terminal output with specific color codes and handling color input from configuration strings.

This module provides low-level terminal interaction capabilities, including color representation and manipulation, ANSI escape sequence generation, terminal display control, and non-blocking input handling. It works with color values, terminal state, and input streams to support tasks like styled output rendering, cursor positioning, screen buffer management, and real-time input processing. Concrete use cases include developing interactive command-line tools, text-based interfaces, terminal emulators, and applications requiring precise control over terminal display and input behavior.
